page.title: 02ECOLOGY OF GREENHALGH AREA
page.content: The land in this block is mostly heavy loam overlying boulder clay and with some moss land where there are numbers of small springs. It is low lying, rising to only 23 metres. There are small areas of mostly deciduous woods with sycamore, ash, beech, birch and elm. Some appear to be dying from age, neglect and Dutch Elm disease. The hedgerows are mainly hawthorn with elderberry, alder, hazel, wild roses, honeysuckle, bramble, blackthorn and crab apples in places. The weather is temperate with occasional extremes. These have recently been experienced. 1984 had a dry hot summer with drought occurring. 1985 had a dry cold spring with a great deal of east wind followed by a wetter than usual summer. The average rainfall for the Fylde, of which this block is a part, is about 44 inches.
